item.title: Tim Kaine and Mike Pence Clash Sharply Over Their Running Mates
item.description: No. 2 candidates always use their debates to promote and defend the top of the ticket, but Mr. Pence’s role came after a week of outbursts from Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MARTIN and PATRICK HEALY

item.title: Debate Takeaways: Tim Kaine Presses Mike Pence on Russia, but Not Gay Rights
item.media:description: Senator Tim Kaine, Democrat of Virginia, left, and Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana, his Republican rival, during the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday in Farmville, Va.
item.description: The two No. 2s in the 2016 race engaged in a snippy, but conventional, tit-for-tat exchange, with Mr. Pence largely sidestepping Mr. Kaine’s attacks on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: ALEXANDER BURNS

item.title: Mike Pence, Tim Kaine, Toronto Blue Jays: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.media:description: Senator Tim Kaine, left, and Gov. Mike Pence threw each other on the defensive at the vice-presidential debate in Farmville, Va., on Tuesday.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
item.dc:creator: SEAN ALFANO

item.title: New York Today: New York Today: A Moment for the Mets
item.media:description: Eyeing a chance to play deeper into October.
item.media:credit: Alex Goodlett for The New York Times
item.description: Wednesday: Dreaming of the World Series, pizza for a good cause, and our city’s Hispanic heritage.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN WOLFE

item.title: California Today: California Today: The Steep Costs of Fighting Wildfires
item.media:description: The cost so far of battling the Soberanes wildfire near Big Sur, seen in August, has been estimated at more than $230 million.
item.media:credit: David Royal/The Monterey County Herald, via Associated Press
item.description: Wednesday: Budgeting to suppress California’s fires, Google unveils its own smartphone, and parting thoughts from the longtime Los Angeles Downtown News publisher.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: News Analysis: Mike Pence’s Defense Strategy: Dodge and Deflect Donald Trump’s Words
item.media:description: Senator Tim Kaine and Gov. Mike Pence, with the moderator Elaine Quijano, at the start of the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday.
item.description: At his debate with Senator Tim Kaine, Mr. Pence seemed to decide that all of the fires that Mr. Trump has set in the past year could not be doused in a single night.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL BARBARO and AMY CHOZICK

item.title: Who Won the Debate? Commentators Give Edge to Mike Pence
item.media:description: Gov. Mike Pence, Donald J. Trump’s running mate, during the vice-presidential debate at Longwood University in Farmville, Va., on Tuesday. Critics praised his temperament in response to questions from his opponent, Senator Tim Kaine.
item.description: Critics noted Mr. Pence’s steady demeanor in response to Tim Kaine’s barrage of questions and provocations.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: Pence and Kaine in Vice-Presidential Debate
item.description: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana and Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia scrambled to defend the policies of their running mates in their only debate at Longwood University in Farmville, Va. The Times reporter Michael D. Shear weighs in on their defensive maneuvers.

item.title: Vice-Presidential Debate: What You Missed
item.media:description: Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia and Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana at the vice-presidential debate at Longwood University in Farmville, Va.
item.description: Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia and Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana faced off at Longwood University in Farmville, Va., in their only debate.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CONFESSORE and MATT FLEGENHEIMER

item.title: Transcript of the 2016 Debate Between the Running Mates
item.description: Following is a transcript of the vice-presidential debate on Tuesday, as transcribed by the Federal News Service.

item.title: Donald Trump as Role Model? G.O.P. Senator ‘Absolutely’ Has Second Thoughts
item.media:description: Senator Kelly Ayotte, Republican of New Hampshire, campaigned in Hudson, N.H., on Tuesday.
item.description: Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire found herself apologizing for praising her party’s presidential candidate as a good role model.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER STEINHAUER

item.description: The Morning Briefing Delivered to your inbox Monday through Friday.

item.title: 3 Makers of ‘World’s Smallest Machines’ Awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry
item.media:description: Winners of the 2016 Nobel Prize in Chemistry, Jean-Pierre Sauvage, J Fraser Stoddart and Bernard L Feringa, are displayed at the Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences in Stockholm on Wednesday as Sara Snogerup Linse, who heads the panel that selects nominees, explains a principle with the aid of a bagel.
item.media:credit: Henrik Montgomery/TT News Agency, via Reuters
item.description: Jean-Pierre Sauvage, J. Fraser Stoddart and Bernard L. Feringa won for “molecular machines” that can be used for the development of new materials, sensors and energy storage systems.
item.dc:creator: KENNETH CHANG and SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Hurricane Matthew Pummels Haiti With Fierce Winds and Rain
item.media:description: Streets were flooded in Port-au-Prince after Hurricane Matthew crashed ashore early Tuesday with 145 m.p.h. winds.
item.description: The top United Nations official in the country described the storm as “the largest humanitarian event” in the nation of 11 million since a devastating earthquake six years ago.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Hurricane Matthew Hits Haiti
item.description: Haiti took precautions as the Category 4 storm made landfall on Tuesday. The storm is expected to cause damaging winds, flash floods and landslides.

item.title: Xi Jinping May Delay Picking China’s Next Leader, Stoking Speculation
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China during a ceremony observing Martyrs’ Day, a holiday that memorializes Chinese who died in battle against foreign powers, at Tiananmen Square in Beijing last week.
item.description: The apparent plan by the Chinese president has unsettled the party elite and created uncertainty over whether Mr. Xi will try to stay in power beyond the usual two terms.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China

item.title: Your Daily Mini Crossword
item.description: Solve a bite-size crossword in just a few minutes.

item.title: News: What We’re Reading
item.description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Tara Parker-Pope, Jazmine Hughes and others.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Sketch Guy: One of the Smartest Money Strategies Is Asking When You Don’t Know
item.description: Humility, in personal finance, is knowing how to ask for help when you don’t know something, even when you think you should know it.
item.dc:creator: CARL RICHARDS

item.title: A French Underground Railroad, Moving African Migrants
item.media:description: Migrants crossed a road near a Red Cross camp outside Ventimiglia, the last Italian city before the French border. The authorities have put about 800 migrant men in the camp.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: Near the border with Italy, a farmer and his network of “citizen smugglers” have helped hundreds cross the border, in a personal response to his nation’s muddled handling of the crisis.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: The Real Message in Ang Lee’s Latest? ‘It’s Just Good to Look At’
item.media:description: The director Ang Lee wearing the glasses that will be needed to view his new movie, “Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk.” It was filmed in 3-D, and it will be shown — in theaters that can accommodate it — at 4K resolution and a rate of 120 frames per second, surpassing any previous major movie release.
item.media:credit: Emily Andrews for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Lee is gambling on an advanced filmmaking technique in “Billy Lynn’s Long Halftime Walk” that audiences have rejected before.
item.dc:creator: DAVE ITZKOFF

item.title: U.S. Election Cycle Offers Kremlin a Window of Opportunity in Syria
item.media:description: The aftermath of Syrian government and Russian airstrikes in a rebel-held neighborhood of Aleppo in July.
item.media:credit: Muhammed Juneyd/Anadolu Agency, via Getty Images
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin, analysts say, is advancing goals in the Syrian conflict while President Obama is on the way out and his replacement is undetermined.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Ethics Panel Investigating de Blasio’s Nonprofit Is Said to Issue Broad Subpoena
item.media:description: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s political nonprofit, the Campaign for One New York, shut down this year. It is being investigated by the State Joint Commission on Public Ethics.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: New requests for communications and other items by a state ethics panel came just days after the Campaign for One New York lost its case in court.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM

item.title: Blue Jays 5, Orioles 2: Edwin Encarnacion’s Homer Lifts Blue Jays Past Orioles in A.L. Wild-Card Game
item.media:description: The Blue Jays’ Edwin Encarnacion after winning the game with a three-run homer. He sent a first-pitch fastball from Ubaldo Jimenez into the second deck at Rogers Centre in Toronto.
item.description: In a battle of home-run-hitting teams, Encarnacion’s three-run shot in the 11th inning sent Toronto to the divisional round, where it will face the Texas Rangers.
item.dc:creator: TYLER KEPNER

item.title: Ex-Ally of Christie Links Cuomo to Cover-Up of Lane Closings
item.media:description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey at a news conference last week. An official said the governors agreed to issue a report falsely explaining the bridge lane closings in 2013 as a traffic study.
item.media:credit: Bryan Thomas for The New York Times
item.description: David Wildstein testified that the governors agreed to issue a report falsely citing a traffic study for closing access lanes to the George Washington Bridge; a Cuomo aide denied the account.
item.dc:creator: KATE ZERNIKE
item.category: Port Authority of New York and New Jersey

item.title: Trinh Thi Ngo, Broadcaster Called ‘Hanoi Hannah’ in Vietnam War, Dies
item.media:description: Trinh Thi Ngo, better known as “Hanoi Hannah,” in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, last year.
item.description: The soft-spoken radio announcer both entertained and reproached American forces.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: The Public Editor: A Look at Clinton’s Marriage Woes Raises a Question: Really?
item.media:description: Hillary Clinton talking to the media on her campaign plane.
item.description: A case can be made, perhaps, for a close look at how Hillary Clinton responded to her husband’s infidelity. But not for this particular story.
item.dc:creator: LIZ SPAYD

item.title: What in the World: In Senegal, Absolution Comes With a Wing and a Prayer
item.description: In Dakar and other cities, men stand on street corners with cages of red-billed firefinches, which people buy and release to get rid of sins and anxiety.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: German Prosecutors Side With Satire, Not Turkish President
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann
item.description: Prosecutors saw no crime in a satirical poem about Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the Turkish president, and dropped charges against a German comedian.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Union Boss (and Former Miss America) Hits the Road in ‘Fun Home’
item.media:description: Kate Shindle as the cartoonist Alison Bechdel in “Fun Home.”
item.description: Kate Shindle will portray lesbian cartoonist Alison Bechdel in the traveling production of the Tony-winning musical while also leading Actors’ Equity.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Facebook Marketplace Goes Wrong: Sex, Guns and Baby Hedgehogs
item.media:description: Posts advertising the sale of illegal drugs were featured on Facebook’s new Marketplace tab on Monday.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: The social media giant says a technical issue allowed inappropriate content to be offered for sale.
item.dc:creator: JONAH ENGEL BROMWICH

item.title: Who Is Elena Ferrante? Supporters Say NOYB
item.media:description: Some of Elena Ferrante’s books translated into English.
item.media:credit: Chris Warde-Jones for The New York Times
item.description: Writers and critics from many quarters responded quickly to an Italian journalist’s excavation of financial records in an effort to identify the author who writes as Elena Ferrante.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL DONADIO and JENNIFER SCHUESSLER

item.title: Nonfiction: ‘The Bitch in the House’ Has a Sequel: ‘The Bitch Is Back’
item.media:description: Cathi Hanauer
item.description: An anthology edited by Cathi Hanauer taps the experiences of women reporting from middle age.
item.dc:creator: LORI GOTTLIEB

item.title: Cultural Studies: The Rise of the ‘Bromosexual’ Friendship
item.media:description: Lucas Whitehead, right, and his roommate Ben Moss in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.
item.media:credit: Andrew White for The New York Times
item.description: The issues that once kept straight men and gay men apart are dissolving, in real life and in popular culture.
item.dc:creator: JIM FARBER

item.title: Women Shun the Maternity Smock, and Stores Race to Catch Up
item.media:description: New fabric technologies, like the blend of nylon and spandex used in this striped top by Rosie Pope, has allowed for stretchier, quick-drying maternity wear.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: The maternity aisle is looking more like a high-end boutique as cultural attitudes about pregnancy shift from bigger and baggier to sleeker and stretchier.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL ABRAMS
